sp.p: I understand you, and I thank you. But before I acccept a love like his, I must feel I deserve it. I dare not owe it to—to—a deception.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: A deception. Helen—Then this story she has told me—

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Was invented to screen me, and to spare you much suffering. It is true, Horace. I must speak out, though I know this confession may separate us for ever. In a moment of sadness and suffering, I was imprudent enough to listen to another's passion.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: (turns away with a groan) When I was so happy!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: My folly went no farther. I gave him no encouragement. I never forgot that I was your wife, Horace!

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Had you known how dear you were to me—

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: You never told me so. I thought your heart had turned from me; but mine was all your own always. Oh, Horace, if you had but revealed to me one tithe of the love for me which you avowed to her just now. I heard it, and even in my mortal terror the words came to me like music. Whatever my lot may be, it will not be a bitter one, now I know you loved me. Leave me if you will—you cannot unsay those blessed words.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: (seizing her in his arms) Leave you, my own dear Helen! what was your fault to mine—your imprudence of an hour to my selfishness of years?

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: You forgive me?—

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: It is for you to forgive me!

div.stage: Enter GENERAL WITHERINGTON, C., comes down, R.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: (HORACE makes signs) Ah, Chetwynd! Excuse me, Lady Helen. Mrs. Wardour, I wouldn't have troubled you again, if I weren't the bearer of news to make even an old "meddler" welcome. Pooh! it's no secret now—they're all talking of your good luck at the Carlton.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: About what?

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Your good luck, dear?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p:
(to MRS. WARDOUR) Hang it, Witherington, let me at least have
the pleasure of announcing my own honours. Who do you think is Fred's new chef on this mission?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Fred's chef! why, you don't mean to say—

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: No less a person than your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: (aside) Good heavens!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (aside) There's all my work to do over again.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: (aside to MRS. WARDOUR) Tell him the truth—you must.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (to LADY HELEN) To have them blow each other's brains out?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Well, my darling, how shall you like doing the honours of the embassy?

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Oh, I shall be so proud, when you are the ambassador.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: I say, Mrs. Wardour, you owe me an apology, I think.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (hastily crosses to R.) Let bygones be bygones, for mercy's sake, General.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: With all my heart—you gave me a tremendous wigging just now; but after all, if it hadn't been for me, I don't suppose Fred would have been appointed.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Why, how did you help him, Witherington?

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: It was through me you got Fred's letter?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: What letter?

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: The one I forwarded to you at Beaurepos', a quarter of an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: (crosses to R., shows him letter) A letter! a quarter of an hour ago! Was this it?

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: (examining it) Eh? dated from the club—quarter past eleven—yes, that's it.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Mrs. Wardour, you hear!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (trembling) Yes! (HORACE draws a long breath, MRS. WARDOUR gives him an imploring look) Forgive me! Forgive him—he is but a boy—pray forgive him—I am his mother.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: (after a struggle, crosses to LADY HELEN, L.) Fear nothing—the lesson is all the better for the change of sex—I can afford to forgive him now.

div.stage: Enter FREDERICK, C. D., comes down R. C.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'm afraid my visit is rather a late one; but as I knew my mother was here, I was anxious to give her news of my appointment, and at the same time to congratulate you, my dear Chetwynd, and to thank you—

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: On the contrary, I have to thank you for a lesson, which a few minutes ago I should have attempted to repay in something more solid than words.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (aside to him) Horace!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: (aside to him) Forget and forgive.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: I'm afraid, my dear Frederick, that the Lisbon air may be dangerous to your health—your mother and Lady Helen both tell me you're liable to disease of the heart. I shall recommend Lord Beaurepos to cancel your appointment. My dear Emily, go and scold your naughty child, while I scold mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.l: More need to scold ourselves, than to scold others.
You read the husband's lesson—I the mother's.
Love of our scapegrace sons too oft may lead us
To follow them where they don't ask or need us.
Like hens who have hatched ducklings, to the pond,
Our brood we follow—fussy—fearful—fond.
But from our play, mammas, this fact set down,
Spite of the hens, ducks will swim and won't drown.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: (touching head) The lightest part, you know, still longest up is,
sp.l: I know how hard it is to keep down puppies.
My dogma is, that boys—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Leave boys alone;
Your dogmatism's but puppyism full grown,
My lesson's learnt too; from love's madness snatched,
Henceforth I'm an attaché unattached.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: It is not love—but folly you've to quell.
Love wisely, and you cannot love too well,
That is the lesson I have learnt to-night—
Learnt it by heart (to HORACE) I hope I've said it right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Come, schoolmaster, your pupil's pains applaud.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Schoolmaster? I! The schoolmaster abroad!
sp.l: I'm fitter far for scholar than for teacher.
Yes, I'm the penitent, (to HELEN) be you the preacher.
Teach me, and all like me, this truth to arrive at,
That public duties need not trench on private—
That, however wide the statesman's thoughts may roam,
"The House" must not usurp it o'er "the Home."
